justification: The article opens by stating that "The Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT; Frederick, 2005) is ... [a] commonly used measure of individual differences in rational thought," explicitly identifying CRT as the instrument for the cognitive-reflection construct.

Under “The Verbal Cognitive Reflection Test,” the authors explain that Sirota et al. (2021) "developed a test containing ten problems" that are verbal only, and in Study 1a they "developed a Polish adaptation of the Verbal Cognitive Reflection Test," tying the verbal CRT to the verbal form of the cognitive-reflection construct.

Throughout the paper, the traditional seven-item version is labeled "Numerical CRT" (e.g., "Participants completed the seven-item open-ended version of the Cognitive Reflection Test"), indicating that this numerical CRT operationalizes numerical cognitive reflection.
In Study 2 the authors state, "We used the Berlin Numeracy Test (BNT; Cokely et al., 2012) as a measure of statistical numeracy," directly linking statistical numeracy to the BNT.
The Methods section specifies, "Subjective numeracy was measured by the 8-item Subjective Numeracy Scale (Fagerlin et al., 2007)," identifying the SNS as the instrument for subjective numeracy.
The article notes, "We used the Polish version of the Abbreviated Math Anxiety Scale (Cipora et al., 2018), containing nine items," clearly pairing math anxiety with the AMAS.

measured_by: International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR) matrix reasoning items
justification: Under Materials, the authors write, "To measure fluid intelligence, we used four matrix reasoning items chosen from the International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR; Condon & Revelle, 2014)," designating ICAR matrices as the fluid-intelligence measure.

In the description of Belief Bias, the paper says, "We used six syllogisms ... participants read two premises and a conclusion … and were asked to indicate whether the conclusion follows," identifying this syllogism set as the tool for measuring belief bias.

The Denominator Neglect section explains, "We used five denominator neglect problems ... participants were asked to choose between drawing tickets from two bowls," making these problems the operational measure of denominator neglect.

For Risk Preference the authors state, "We used eight risk preference problems ... participants indicated whether they prefer the sure or risky option," showing these problems constitute the risk-preference measure.
The Time Preference section notes, "We used five items ... participants indicated whether they preferred a reward immediately or after a delay," defining those items as the time-preference measure.
The paper says the 24-item Rational-Experiential Inventory "contains two main scales: Rational and Experiential," so the Rational scale of the REI measures the rational processing-style construct.
The same paragraph specifies the "Experiential" scale of the Rational-Experiential Inventory, linking it to measurement of experiential processing style.

Under Superstition, the authors state, "we decided to use a scale measuring superstition that was developed in Poland (Sosnowski & Wiech, 2006). The version ... contained five items," identifying this KOP20 scale as the superstition measure.
They report, "we used a Polish translation of the Religious Beliefs Scale by Pennycook et al. (2017). Participants responded to six items," showing this scale operationalizes religious-beliefs.
